citeinfo.title: Changes in Anthropogenic Influences on Streams and Rivers: Timber and forest Cutting

descript.abstract: This dataset consists of three tables representing the percent of forest that has been changed by management activities such as timber or forest cutting. Data were derived from the U.S. Conterminous NAWQA Wall-to-wall Anthropogenic Landuse Trends (NWALT) dataset annually for the period 1999-2012. One table represents percents by Hydrologic Unit Code-10 areas, one by Level IV ecoregion areas, and one by county areas.
descript.purpose: These data are intended to provide a framework in which watershed-specific studies of water quality in streams and rivers may be analyzed. The focus of the data is on anthropogenic changes over time.
descript.supplinf: Three comma-separated text files are given here. Each file contains a "uniqid" field, which is the link to the data in other datasets in this product. The file representing HUC-10 areas has 15,458 rows, the file representing Level IV ecoregions has 967 rows, and the file representing U.S. counties has 3,109 rows. Data were derived from Timber supplemental geospatial rasters published as part of the NWALT dataset (Falcone, 2015), which were in turn derived primarily from USGS LANDFIRE disturbance data (https://www.landfire.gov/disturbance.php; U.S. Geological Survey, 2018). The NWALT Timber data are 60-meter (m) national rasters mapping areas which were likely to have been modified via anthropogenic forestry activites, and exclude natural disturbances such as forest forest or pest infestations. Citations for the boundaries used are: HUC-10 boundaries: National Resources Conservation Service, 2017; Level IV ecoregion boundaries: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, 2013; 2010 counties: National Historical Geographic Information System, 2013. References: Falcone, J.A., 2015, U.S. conterminous wall-to-wall anthropogenic land use trends (NWALT), 1974-2012. U.S. Geological Survey Data Series 948, 33 p. plus appendices 3-6 as separate files, http://dx.doi.org/10.3133/ds948. National Historical Geographic Information System, 2013, U.S. geographic summary data and boundary files, 2010: National Historical Geographic Information System, Integrated Public Use Microdata Series (IPUMS), county boundaries, accessed February 1, 2013 at: https://www.nhgis.org/. National Resources Conservation Service, 2017, Watershed boundary dataset (WBD): National Resources Conservation Service, U.S. Department of Agriculture, available at https://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/main/national/technical/nra/geo/, accessed January 9, 2018 from https://nrcs.app.box.com/v/huc/folder/39640323180. U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, 2013, Level IV ecoregions of the conterminous United States: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development â€“ National Health and Environmental Effects Research Laboratory, accessed November 17, 2017 at: https://www.epa.gov/eco-research/level-iii-and-iv-ecoregions-continental-united-states. U.S. Geological Survey LANDFIRE Program, 2018, LANDFIRE, U.S. Geological Survey, https://www.landfire.gov/.

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted.

vertacc.vertaccr: A formal accuracy assessment of the vertical positional information in the data set has either not been conducted, or is not applicable.

srcinfo.srccontr: HUC-10 boundaries used in data calculations.
County boundaries used in data calculations.

citeinfo.title: Level III and IV ecoregions of the continental United States

srcinfo.srccontr: Level IV ecoregion boundaries used in data calculations.

citeinfo.title: U.S. conterminous wall-to-wall anthropogenic land use trends (NWALT), 1974-2012

srcinfo.srccontr: Source dataset from which timber data are derived. Timber rasters are a series of published supplemental rasters in the NWALT dataset.

procstep.procdesc: (1) Source data are supplemental Timber rasters published as part of the NWALT dataset (Falcone, 2015).
(2) Percent of the HUC-10s, Level IV ecoregions, and counties were calculated using the zonalmean() command in ArcGIS Grid.

enttyp.enttypl: Attribute Table for land modified via anthropogenic forest activities data
enttyp.enttypd: Data consist of comma-separated text files. There are three tables: timber-county.txt, timber-eco4.txt, timber-huc10.txt
enttyp.enttypds: Surface Water Trends project, USGS National Water Quality Program

attr.attrdefs: Unique integer ID used for internal processing and for linking data from other tables

attrdomv.udom: Unique identifier for either "huc10"s, "county"s, or "eco4"s, where YYYY represents one of those three terms

attr.attrdef: Percent timber or forest cutting for year XXXX (1999-2012) (year represented by XXXX) for HUC-10 areas
Percent timber or forest cutting for year XXXX (1999-2012) (year represented by XXXX) for Level IV ecoregion areas
Percent timber or forest cutting for year XXXX (1999-2012) (year represented by XXXX) for US counties
